text.p: Here are the highlights of stories in Serbian and Montenegrin press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories nor does it vouch for their accuracy.
-- S E R B I A --
NASA BORBA
- U.S envoy Robert Gelbard warned Bosnian Serbs that failure to cooperate on implementation of the Dayton agreement (regarding police arrangements) will have serious consequences.

- Road corridor Ljubljana-Zagreb-Belgrade-Nis-Salonika with two forks Belgrade-Budapest and Nis-Sofia was included in priority of Europe's transport development at a recent European transport ministers' conference in Helsinki.
- International mediator on the succession of ex-Yugoslavia Sir Arthur Watts will visit Belgrade, Zagreb and Sarajevo in mid July.
- Yugoslav Deputy Prime Minister Danko Djunic has invited the Salomon Brothers investment bank to visit Belgrade on July 16 to examine possibilities of working in this terriotry.
- Jugooceanija shipping company from Kotor is overhauling its four vessels unblocked by the U.S. and has secured a $14 million loan from Berliner bank from London for the purchase of two new ships.
- As of July 31 Slovenia will withdraw refugee status to some 2,000 Bosnians who come from the part of Bosnia where their nation makes up the majority.
- Croatian customs system enters into force on the Eastern Slavonian border with Yugoslavia from July 1.
- Yugoslav expert group in Moscow is preparing a meeting between Yugoslav trade minister Borisav Vukovic and Russian deputy economy Minister Alexander Sapovaran scheduled for Wednesday.

- Cigarette smuggling alone has cost the state about 50 million German marks a month in public revenues while gray economy has taken over more than 50 percent of GDP, says Yugoslav Deputy Prime Minister Vojin Djukanovic.
- Statistics again show drop of birth rate in Serbia.
- The Serbian government will liberalise fertiliser imports but not before the year 2000 to protect domestic fertiliser producers until they are ready for international competition.
VECERNJE NOVOSTI
- Steel works Sartid from Smederevo and Zenica from Bosnia signed a long term cooperation agreement. First deliveries expected in mid July.

- Yugoslavs travelling to Eastern Slavonia will be required to have Croatian visas from July 1 when Croatian customs authorities take over the border between the region and Yugoslavia, said Croatian consul in Yugoslavia Neven Vrankovic.
- Storms destroyed 138,000 hectares of crops in Vojvodina province. Damage is estimated at over 337 million dinars.
POLITIKA EKSPRES

- Belgraders went out on the streets to celebrate Yugoslavia's victory in a European basketball championship match against Croatia played in Spain on Monday. This is the first time Yugoslav and Croatian basketball teams played each other since the breakup of the former Yugoslavia.
-- M O N T E N E G R O --
POBJEDA
- U.S. Special envoy Robert Gelbard will visit Podgorica on Wednesday. Gelbard and his seven man team will hold talks with Montenegrin President Momir Bulatovic and Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic.

- Five officials of the Democratic Party of Socialists (DPS) will compete for the DPS nomination for the presidential election -- president Momir Bulatovic, deputy prime ministers Svetozar Marovic, Milo Djukanovic and Milica Pejanovic Djurisic and member of the party executive board Milan Gajovic. -- Belgrade newsroom +381 11 311-4305
